pageContext.claim: “In 2019, income inequality fell for the second straight year. The income gap widened under the Obama-Biden administration, and it widened fairly substantially, and it narrowed under the Trump administration. So there's a little fact that you didn't know.”
pageContext.analysis: Trump is wrong about this. During the presidency of the first billionaire president, the nation’s 200-or-so wealthiest people -- a cohort representing 0.00006% of the population -- increased their combined wealth by a staggering $1 trillion. "U.S. workers were seeing wage gains and ultra-low unemployment before the coronavirus hit. Adjusted for inflation, the median household income rose 6.8% last year to $68,703, after rising just 1.8% and 0.5% in Trump’s first two years in office," noted Bloomberg News."Millionaires and billionaires had far more to celebrate. A Republican overhaul of the tax code left wealthy investors and corporations paying lower overall tax rates than most working professionals. It’s also never been easier to avoid the U.S. estate and gift tax, and pass on wealth to heirs. When Covid-19 hit, the Treasury and Federal Reserve propped up markets, primarily benefiting the top 1%, who own the majority of stocks held by U.S. households."
